titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Archives Staff

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-04-04 12:06:09 -0400.

did.physloc: Robert Rauschenberg Foundation 381 Lafayette Street, New York
did.abstract: Robert Rauschenberg, an American artist, worked in a wide range of subjects, styles, materials, and techniques and has been called a forerunner of essentially every postwar movement sinceAbstract Expressionism. He remained, however, independent of any particular affiliation. Active from the late-1940s to 2008, his practice embodied lifelong commitment to collaboration and he worked performers, printmakers, engineers, writers, artists, and artisans from around the world.

This draft ONLY includes information on the included series. Once the Robert Rauschenberg papers are completely processed, series drafts will be combined into a single "Guide to the Robert Rauschenberg papers" (finding aid), which will supersede all drafts.

arrangement.head: Arrangement:
arrangement.p: Organized into series: 1. Correspondence; 2. Performance; and 3. Writings and Notes

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation:
prefercite.p: Robert Rauschenberg papers. RRFA01. Robert Rauschenberg Foundation Archives.

arrangement.head: Arrangement:
arrangement.p: The series is arranged alphabetically by artist, choreographer, performance group, or performance event.

scopecontent.head: Summary:
scopecontent.p: The Performance series contains materials related to performances in which Robert Rauschenberg created, collaborated, or participated, as well as select documentation of performances by collaborators and friends. The bulk of the series is paper documentation ranging from handwritten or typed notes, sketches, and scores by Rauschenberg and collaborators to printed materials such as flyers, posters and programs publicizing and documenting the events. Highlights of the series include Rauschenberg's costume design sketches for Merce Cunningham, Rauschenberg's notes and supply lists for his performances, and Rauschenberg's notebooks documenting his participation in multiple works by various artists.

This series does not contain photographs or audiovisual materials. Photographs documenting performance events are located in the Photograph collection (RRFA09). Audiovisual materials documenting performance events are located in the Audiovisual collection (RRFA02). Additional materials related to Open Score can be found in the Projects and Exhibitions series under E.A.T (draft unavailable as of 1.8.2016).
